Issues.Title: Incorrectly triggering dragenter and dragleave events in v-for loop - continuation to #4479
Issues.Body:
### Version
2.6.10

### Reproduction link
[https://jsfiddle.net/Eggon666/d6htzpr0/12/](https://jsfiddle.net/Eggon666/d6htzpr0/12/)







### Steps to reproduce
Drag the buttons (on Windows, Chrome). Watch console.log reports on number of button on which dragenter/dragleave event was triggered - for buttons 3-5 the number might be incorrect. The bug sometimes needs a few drags before it triggers. 

### What is expected?
First dragenter/dragleave event triggering inside the dragged element should trigger only on the element that is being dragged (unless the pointer moves over another element).

### What is actually happening?
**Dragenter** and **dragleave** events are triggered on an incorrect (i.e. **preceding sibling**) element from **v-for** loop **together with or instead of** the events of the actually dragged element (DragTarget). The problem seems to be related to v-for specifically, I haven’t encountered it on non-v-for’ed elements. It appears on Chrome only.

Bug behavior is erratic. There are 5 elements rendered with v-for:

1) The problem does not always occur on the first drag

2) Buttons 1 and 2 always work fine

3) Button 3 sometimes works fine and sometimes does not trigger any dragenter/dragleave event at all

4) Buttons 4 and 5:

  a.	sometimes work fine (rarely),

  b.	sometimes they trigger events only on the preceding element (eg dragging No 4 triggers dragenter/leave on No 3)

  c.	sometimes they trigger events on both the dragged element and the preceding element. In such case the order is: 1) PrecedingSibling.DragEnter 2) DragTarget.DragEnter 3) PrecedingSibling.DragLeave 4) DragTarget.DragLeave

  d.	However, if you start the drag and don’t move the pointer outside of the DragTarget the bug is **very unlikely** to occur! If it occurs it never triggers PrecedingSibling only, it triggers both elements: 1) PrecedingSibling.DragEnter 2) DragTarget.DragEnter 3) PrecedingSibling.DragLeave (the latter is therefore not connected with DragTarget.DragLeave, but happens automatically regardless) 

  e.	On the other hand, if you move the pointer out of the element immediately after drag start, the bug is very likely to occur.

  f.	When the dragenter is triggered on the DragTarget again, i.e. when you move the pointer out of the element and come back into it – the sibling event is not triggered anymore, just on the very beginning of the drag.

Bug is present on all 3 versions of Vue in js fiddle and on Vue 2.6.10 in my project.

---
This is the same problem as was submitted in unresolved issue **#4479**. I can reproduce the behavior from the jsfiddle mentioned in #4479 on my PC. I hope this submission can shed some more light on the problem, because I noticed some more nuances.

Bug behavior on my local project (Vue 2.6.10) is slightly different than the one from my fiddle described above. The setup is slightly different as well (v-for is used on components which have some nested divs in them). Bug behavior:

1) The problem does not always occur on the first drag

2) Once the problem occurs for the first time it occurs on every consecutive drag – except for element no 2 which can behave correctly again.

3) Dragging element triggers dragenter/dragleave triggers on both the dragged element and on the preceding v-for sibling (sibling first) or just on the preceding sibling. When the dragenter is triggered on the DragTarget again, i.e. when you move the pointer on the child div or when you leave the element and come back into it – the sibling event is not triggered anymore, just on the beginning of the drag.

The difference between js fiddle and local behavior is mainly (but not only) frequency of particular behaviors. On the local setup:

a. second v-for element is also affected, although can react correctly sometimes (in fiddle second is not affected),

b. third element very rarely ignores the drag (in fiddle it is much more frequent)

c. starting from third element rendered by v-for, once the bug occurs, it will occur every time (although will still randomly oscillate between triggering on preceding sibling only or two elements together),

d. the fact of not moving the cursor out of the DragTarget does not prevent the bug from happening (in contrary to jsfiddle description point 4.d ). This might be caused by children divs?

Problem occurs on my two computers (Win7 HP and Win7 Professional), only on Chrome (74.0.3729.157). Mozilla and IE work fine. On one of the computers I removed Chrome with all extensions and history and reinstalled it. The problem persisted. Kaspersky’s Chrome extension is unfortunately automatically loaded on Chrome install, though not activated. Turning off Kaspersky on Windows did not prevent the extension from loading, and I don’t know how to prevent it other than uninstalling Kaspersky which I’d rather not do. Removing the Kaspersky’s extension from Chrome does not change the situation though.

PS. This is my second submission of this issue. Previous was closed by the bot, because I used "reference in new issue" option from my comment to #4479. I thought that linking them this way would be more useful than going through the template. Please consider adding explicit clarification on how to submit issues "reopening" previously closed issues  and/or a issue reference field to the template. I read the documentation, but didnt find it. Sorry for inconvenience.

Issues.Title: Testing plugin in development: two instances of Vue loaded
Issues.Body:
### Version
2.6.10

### Reproduction link
[https://github.com/fikkatra/common-vue-components](https://github.com/fikkatra/common-vue-components)







### Steps to reproduce
* git clone https://github.com/fikkatra/common-vue-components.git
* cd common-vue-components
* npm i
* npm run build
* cd demo
* npm i
* npm run serve




### What is expected?
The Banner.vue component can call the vuex store by calling `this.$store`.

### What is actually happening?
An error `TypeError: Cannot read property 'state' of undefined` is thrown. Reason: `this.$store` is undefined, because multiple instances of Vue are loaded.

---
I'm developing a Vue plugin that contains common components, to be reused across multiple client applications.

The common component plugin is accompanied by a 'demo' application to immediately test the plugin components while they're still in development.

The plugin requires vuex, which is passed from the client application through the plugin options.

All is fine when I publish the plugin to npm, then import it into the demo app through npm. However, when I directly reference the plugin code (because I'm still developing the plugin and I don't want to publish yet), I get a console error: 
> TypeError: Cannot read property 'state' of undefined

This happens when using either of the following methods, all commonly used to test an npm package that is still under development:
* npm link
* in demo/package.json: `"vue-common-components": "file:.."`
* `import CommonComponentsPlugin from "../../src/index";` (handy for live reloading)

After searching and with the help of [this issue](https://github.com/vuejs/vuex/issues/842) and [this Stack Overflow question](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/49585845/attrs-is-readonly-listeners-is-readonly-avoid-mutating-a-prop-directly),  I understand that the error occurs because there are **two instances of Vue loaded**. 

However: where is this second instance coming from? I'm confused, because I pass the Vue instance to the common components plugin via the install function. So why is it loaded twice?

I tried to solve this by placing the following in demo/vue.config.js, but this doesn't solve the issue.
```
const path = require('path');

module.exports = {
	configureWebpack: {
		resolve: {
			modules: [path.resolve(__dirname, './node_modules')],
		},
	},
};
```

Issues.Title: Directive for both v-bind and v-on
Issues.Body:
### What problem does this feature solve?
I have several cases of components with different views, the children of these components are almost the same, but have some key differences, I want my code to be DRY and give the implementation in a base Component 

Imagine i have a component with this template:
```html
<template>
  <component is="myView" :textOptions="textOptions" />
</template>
```
Whatever view is chosen, there's always a text component inside that uses these textOptions like so:
```html
<TextComponent v-bind="textOptions.props" v-on="textOptions.listeners" :otherProps=" 'other' " />
```


### What does the proposed API look like?
I propose a new directive (which I'm calling v-all for now)
```html
 <TextComponent v-all="textOptions" />
```

Issues.Title: Undocumented breaking change of checkbox/radio in 2.6.0
Issues.Body:
### Version
2.6.0

### Reproduction link
[https://jsfiddle.net/goblinlord/k64bx8gp/9/](https://jsfiddle.net/goblinlord/k64bx8gp/9/)







### Steps to reproduce
1. Create an element with `type` attribute set to either `checkbox` or `radio`.
2. Call `preventDefault` on the `click` event (or just set `@click.prevent`)
3. Set the `checked` value synchronously to a different value

### What is expected?
New value that is set should be reflected in the rendered markup.

### What is actually happening?
The result of the value changing is not reflected in the in the rendered state even though the value is actually changed based on what is shown in Vue dev tools.

---
This worked prior to `2.6.0` and I can not find any documentation indicating the behavior changed or why it would change.  In the reproduction link you can comment out the `2.6.0` version and uncomment the line above it with `2.5.22`.  On `2.5.22` it works as expected.

I have been using this previously when wrapping an input with a styled alternative with additional markup/styling.  The purpose of having `preventDefault` is to allow the decision of the value change to be made in a location other than the checkbox itself.  For example, we could easily display a dialog box when the user clicks this and then when it is closed set the state based on the response.  Removing `preventDefault` causes the checkbox to toggle.  If this happens but we want to wait until a later time to set the state, the desired state is not reflected properly until that time.  Some cases, no async work is done and it is desirable to change state immediately.  In those cases, a simple `v-model` can be used with the same exact component.

A dialog box is just one example, I also have cases where there is an network call before the actual state is changed.  (one style is a toggle slider for example but i have other styled inputs as well)

Issues.Title: Support for apps loaded from Windows file shares
Issues.Body:
When loading an application from a Windows file share (not mapped to a network letter), Chrome will throw an error (`cannot be created in a document with origin 'null'`) when `replaceState` is called. This happens because while `protocol` is `file:` and `host` is `vboxsvr` the `origin` is `file://` as opposed to `file://vboxsvr`. This means the absolute path is not created correctly.

Only Windows shares that are not mapped to a drive letter are affected. If a drive letter is mapped then while origin will still be `file://`, pathname will include the information instead (e.g. `/Z:/dist/index.html`)

This code removes the reliance on the origin attribute and calculates the absolute path from `protocol` and `host`.

Issues.Body:
This PR provides a fix to the issue #2607.

Reproduction link

https://jsfiddle.net/Rocka/bhu5vkn8/3/

In abstract mode, if you try to navigate through your history with the same routes appearing consecutively in your stack history, the history index remains unchanged.

In History or Hash mode, this issue does not appear because history navigation is handled by the browser and not by vue-router. In all modes, we do not want to re-render a page if the current route and the next route are identical. However, in the case of abstract mode, we still need to update the history index whenever the current and next routes are the same since AbstractHistory handles its own history stack.

Issues.Title: Creating a type declaration for `next`
Issues.Body:
### What problem does this feature solve?
At the moment there is a type definition for `NavigationGuard` in `router.d.ts`. This works nicely. Within that, the `next` argument is a function that accepts a union of different types as argument.

```ts
next: (to?: RawLocation | false | ((vm: V) => any) | void) => void
```

I think it'd be neat to easily use this just like the `Route` interface declaration in, for example, a components navigation guard.

### What does the proposed API look like?
Export a type definition maybe called `NavigationGuardCallback` in `router.d.ts`.

```ts
export type NavigationGuardCallback = (to?: RawLocation | false | ((vm: V) => any) | void) => void;

export type NavigationGuard<V extends Vue = Vue> = (
  to: Route,
  from: Route,
  next: NavigationGuardCallback
) => any;
```

Issues.Title: Disable Direct State Mutation Outside of Mutation Handlers, at Least in Strict Mode
Issues.Body:
### What problem does this feature solve?
As [doc](https://vuex.vuejs.org/guide/strict.html) said, 

> In strict mode, whenever Vuex state is mutated outside of mutation handlers, an error will be thrown. 

However, **state will still be mutated** though an error would be thrown. 

In my opinion, this behavior is weird and misleading. Normally,  operation would fail if an error showed. But in this case, it didn't. 

Also, if a developer doesn't see this error and only see the result which is actually worked, he might do this behavior all the time until one day he find the error.

 So, my propose is

>  Why Not Disable Direct State Mutation Outside of Mutation Handlers, at Least in Strict Mode?

There should be a way to absolutely disable direct state mutation outside of mutation handlers. 

### What does the proposed API look like?
```js
const store = new Vuex.Store({
  // ...
  strict: true
})
```
Direct state mutation outside of mutation handlers would be disabled when `strict` is true.
